author: jamieg90
title: Non-Fungible Collectables
description: Trading collectable items through traditional avenues is costly, time-consuming and illiquid.

f6_assessments.q0:
Starting with the problem statement, the proposal mentions that trading collectable items is costly, time-consuming and illiquid. These downsides of the collectables market are definitely real: collectables are by definition unique, and thus illiquid, and time consuming. The costly aspect probably depends a lot on the market: art collectibles that have to be stored properly in order not to degrade over time likely incur higher trading costs than trading cards which are easier to store, transport and sell. 

Let’s look at the value proposition. The proposers’ plan is to build a marketplace for NFTs backed by certified physical, real world collectables. Here is how things would work. Verified sellers would deposit the collectables at a location in London, and an NFT would be issued to represent that item. Owners of those NFTs can, at any time, redeem their physical item. In the meantime, the items would be fully insured and can be audited by “anyone wishing to do so, as long as this person has been approved by the community”. 

We don’t have many other details, and I have to ask a significant number of questions, what-if scenarios and stress testing the business model. Please bear with me:

- can we have more details on what that location in London would imply? What kind of security measures are in place and what volume of collectibles can it hold? What collectible items would it target at first? Does the team own it? How would its costs be passed on to the marketplace?
 - if the project is successful, that means a significant physical value would be stored in that London based vault. How would NFT owners gain comfort that the items are safe from theft if under the control of one central party, the NFT marketplace? Would a custodian be appointed to ensure a higher level of trust?
- who would be the verified sellers, businesses or private persons? Would they act as custodians of the items in the London vault?
- How would the physical items be ring-fenced from the marketplace’s balance sheet? Are there any contingency measures in place in case the marketplace goes bust? Who would ensure that the items in store are sent to their rightful NFT owners and not end up being liquidated in case of default?
- storing the items over a period of time would incur costs? Would there be annual storage fees and retrieval fees? If yes, what is the pricing model of such fees? 
- how would the marketplace address the global market, or would it only be limited in the UK? What about performing KYC controls before a user redeems an item?

I shall limit my questions to the ones above - but for me they are a clear demonstration that the business model definitely needs, if not perfecting, at least being better explained to the Cardano community before the benefits of such a model become evident. Until then, despite the excellent connection between the proposal and the challenge, I have to limit my assessment to three stars.
f6_assessments.q1:
There is a somewhat good, but definitely not perfect, description of the team. The proposal mentions four names: James and Arnas, with backgrounds in the collectables and auctioning industries, Tashoma the UI/UX designer and co-founder of liqwid.finance, and Jemini, responsible for video production, marketing and branding. An excellent proposal would have definitely included some social media profiles for an easy way to verify the team’s profile and previous experiences. The team also lacks, for the moment, internal development competencies and are in talks with Haskell teams. 

The timeline is the following: designing and creating the marketplace would take 18 weeks. The proposal mentions that users would have a chance to experiment with the testnet, but it does not tell if the target for testnet or mainnet is after 18 weeks - so things are rather fuzzy. There are sadly no intermediary milestones, just a storyline: initially, trading would start in “the most established certified collectable markets”: banknotes, coins, comics, trading cards and video games. Marketing efforts would then be undertaken, and the target would be to onboard the first 1.000 participants. After, user base expansion would follow. 

Budgetwise, the platform build would require 150k USD. Additionally two employees would require 25k USD each per year, and they would handle marketing, promotion, engagement, admin duties, storage, and issuance / redemption of NFTs. Initial set-up costs are also included for 50k USD: insurance, deposit boxes, maintenance, marketing.  

I have again a set of questions:
- The proposers claim that “a significant amount of Coin collectables are already secured from our first registered seller” who is that registered seller and what is the total value of coins secured?
- if they are still in talks with developer teams, how do the proposers know that the build would require 150k USD? How many quotes have they obtained, and from whom? Do they have a more detailed budget with necessary tasks, hours needed and hourly rates charged by the outside developers? 
- how would the marketplace make money, what is the overall revenue model? 
- how would possible cost overruns be handled, and does the team plan on deploying their own capital to fund the marketplace? 

In conclusion, there are still many unknowns regarding this project’s feasibility: more details are needed about the team, the budget needs a more thorough look and the development stages are not very clear either. Similarly as in the previous section, three stars are sufficient.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposers mention that they would issue monthly reports with information on users, trading activity, user feedback and demographic indicators. Performance indicators would include number of active users (retail, institutional) and questionnaires to trace the user acquisition process, mainly from which market have they joined the marketplace. Sadly, the proposal does not offer clear success metrics in terms of number of users after a certain time, or a target volume of trades / collectible items stored. 

I would have also expected that the team would have set-up by now, or at least promised to have in the future, a website with more details on the marketplace, roadmap and team, as well as digital communications channels with the target community / enthusiasts. 

Lacking these ingredients but still delivering a fair auditability case, four stars are appropriate in this case.
f6_assessments.reply: Thank you for the incredibly detailed response and constructive feedback. Collectables will be stored in one of the most secure safety deposit facilities in the UK, and we are able to upgrade space as required by volume. Should the company go bust, the assets belong to the owners of the NFTs rather than the company and this will be stated clearly in our terms. We will implement similar procedures that auction houses and other similar businesses use to vet those who wish to redeem, which will involve verifying their identity to ensure they are not a sanctioned person or otherwise ineligible to redeem such an item.

f6_assessments.q0: The problem statement is clear, showing the limits of traditional Collectable Items Trading and implying that this proposal demonstrates a more efficient way. this problem is well related to the challenge, because its solution is to build an NFT marketplace where the NFTs are backed by certified physical collectables. Which could help grow and increase adoption for Cardano. Its positive impact for the ecosystem is conscious and clearly explained: “to offer lower costs, easier access and greater liquidity”. The KPIs are rather in line with those of the challenge and it is specified that normally this proposal would not need another fund.
f6_assessments.q1: The members of the team are well identifiable as well as their skills which seem to be consistent with the needs of the project, however I did not find any links, or others to prove their activity, which would have been really necessary . Or a link to a site or other means of identification. The budget is clear and well broken down into different stages, but as it is quite high, it would have been really important for us to be able to identify the people who initiated the project, for an additional index of confidence. Links leading to elements on the previous achievements of the participants for example… The plan is rather precise it could have specified a little more indices of temporality or a more precise chronology to realize the timetable. The technical aspects are well addressed as well as the risks, with solutions to mitigate them.
f6_assessments.q2: It would have been useful to cite the specific means by which the team plans to receive feedback from the community. In general, more precision on the means chosen to share the evolution of the project with the community would have been important. But the KPIs make sense and allow rather well to be able to observe the evolution of the project, with a recognizable will of the team in the transparency of their approach. Unless I'm mistaken, I didn't exactly understand how much time the team is giving itself to complete this project.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposed idea would bring a big benefit to the Blockchain space and would most likely bring new customers to Cardano since it would bring more utility to NFTs and it would be an easy way to auction off real world assets. 
The marketplace would leverage the strength of blockchain and combine it with the strengths of the real world.
If the team would succeed this proposal could have a huge positive impact on the whole community since it would open a whole new avenue of business.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team is planing to build a novel solution which is not easy. The information the team provides about themselves and their qualification is really thin which makes it hard to evaluate if they are a good fit for the task.
Furthermore the team does not provide an adequate timeline, milestone plan or budget breakdown. All of those things are necessary to evaluate the feasibility of the project and determine if the community should fund the project. 
If all the info above would be provided the score could be much higher.

The info which the team has provided is lacking but the only thing we have. With that information and the knowledge about the SCs which go open source in the near future it seems somewhat likely that they succeed in implementing the proposed solution.
f6_assessments.q2:
The team provides insufficient information to audit the development process. The community is the investor and one of the main stakeholders in this project and in that capacity we need sufficient information to audit the development. Information which is needed is a detailed timeline, milestones and budget breakdowns. 
Furthermore the team needs a communication strategy to keep the community up to date. 
All the above are lacking which makes the audit process really hard.
Since the team provides some KPIs and milestones they will get 2 stars but need to improve significantly!

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal aims for a solution to create a lower cost, less time, and more liquidity for transactions in the collectable items market. In the traditional method, item owners and customers must pay amounts to intermediary organizations such as auction houses. The proposer will create an NFT marketplace that supports the trading of certified real-world collections. Verified items will be sent to a secure location in London, and the item's owner will receive a corresponding NFT. Once the transaction is completed, this NFT will be transferred to the buyer, and they use this NFT to exchange for the item in real life. Eventually, the converted NFT will be burnt and permanently removed from circulation. An NFT marketplace on the Cardano ecosystem fulfills current business needs and opens up a vibrant collectibles marketplace on the Cardano platform. The Cardano community will benefit from redeemable NFTs. In addition, traditional collectors will also benefit from lower fees, greater liquidity, and safe storage of their items. The content of this proposal reminds me of safes at Swiss banks, but instead of holding the key to the safe, customers bring the NFT in. This NFT transfer is much simpler and faster than a physical key.
f6_assessments.q1: The members behind this project all have years of experience in the collectibles market, and of course, the software developers involved in this project are indispensable. However, a testimonial profile, such as on Linked, will help us better understand the capabilities of the recommending team. The 1-year roadmap includes the implementation steps described in detail. I think adding timelines, such as the amount of work completed in the first three months, will help the community better understand the proposal's progress. The $250,000 budget is allocated: $150,000 for the platform build quoted, $50,000 salary for two employees for one year (marketing, promotion, engagement, day-to-day admin, storage, redemption, issuance of new NFTs, and issuing newsletters), and $50,000 for initial set-up costs. In general, I believe in successfully implementing the author's proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: User roles are critical to the success of the project. The team proposes to prepare suitable marketing solutions to reach interested people in the collectibles market and blockchain community. They also considered the lack of funds during the implementation of this project. Metrics to track proposal progress include the number of active users on the developed platform, growth in different user demographics, the number of users from the traditional collectors' industry, etc. The first 1000 market participants are the target that has been set after one year of project implementation. Based on the information provided, I appreciate the transparency of this proposal.
f6_assessments.reply: Thank you for taking the time to assess our project.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal asks for funding for the development of an NFT marketplace where the NFTs are backed by certified physical collectables.
The problem is clearly presented: lack of liquidity, high costs and time wasted for the trading of collectables.
“The Cardano ecosystem does not have an NFT marketplace that allows users to redeem physical collectables”
The solution presented is to build an alternative, NFT marketplace.
The impact could be significant and in line with the Dapps, Products & Integrations challenge goals and metrics. “The collectables market as a whole is worth roughly $370 billion as of 2020.”
I strongly agree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer foresees some challenges but presents mitigation plans for reducing the risk.
There is a detailed plan presented, however the majority of the funding of that proposal only covers the first point of the set plan for a total of 18 weeks. And being presented within one point of the plan, there are no details involved regarding the development of the NFT marketplace that allows users to redeem physical collectables. Here I have to take half a point.
The budget of that proposal is clearly written by sectors, however the budget is not broken down in detail, work hours/expertise/hourly wage.  Here I have to take half a point
The team that is going to work on this project is presented by name and some stated qualifications and experiences, however there are no CVs, linkedin profiles or other supporting documents. Here I have to take a point.
I neither agree nor disagree that the project plans and budget supplied is feasible to deliver successful implementation.
f6_assessments.q2:
For the auditability of the project the proposer wants to create monthly reports for the new users, trading activity etc. However more than half of the budget is spent on the building of an NFT marketplace, but the proposer does not provide any means of auditing the progress of that development.
There are success metrics presented but they are nothing to way them against. 
There are no milestones or timeline presented against which to compare the progress of the project.
I disagree that this proposal provides me with sufficient information to assess the progress in attaining its stated goals.
Dear proposer, you have a valuable idea, however your proposal needs work. Please consider reading the Proposal Assessor Guide - Fund9 in order to get insights what you have to include in your proposal in order to be rated with higher marks from the PAs.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal involves building an NFT marketplace for the collectibles market, where certified physical collectibles will back the NFTs. The collectibles ownership can be transferred between parties exchanging NFTs on this platform. This solution offers lower costs, easier access, and greater liquidity for the collectibles market. This is a good use case for NFTs, and if the project is executed successfully, it will add value to the Cardano ecosystem and have a positive impact.

The proposer does not mention the geographical focus area of the proposal but states that the physical collectibles will be stored in a secured London-based location. The proposer already has one registered seller who is selling the coin collectibles.

Regarding the risks, the proposer mentions two risks, out of which I think the risk of 'lack of interest' should be concerned more as the success of the protocol depends on it. But as the proposer allocated a budget for marketing efforts, it will likely help tackle this risk and ensure the onboarding of at least sufficient users required to sustain the platform.

Apart from the above positive points, the proposer did not provide the details of how he will build the NFT marketplace, and also, no budget break-up is given based on the identifiable tasks. Hence I cannot agree or disagree with the impact criteria of this proposal.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer stated four team members' details and mentioned that he is in talks with Haskell developers. One of the members is the co-founder of Liqwid Finance. But, the proposer did not provide the LinkedIn profiles of the members. Anyhow, the team seems capable of executing the proposal.

Unfortunately, the proposer did not provide a detailed plan for building the NFT marketplace. Instead, it only consists of the steps of the business plan.

The requested budget of $250k is not reasonable. Also, it is not broken up as per the guidelines. The proposer should have provided the break-up into identifiable tasks. The budget is stated with three types of expenses, i.e., Platform Build -> $150k, Marketing & Other Exps -> $50k, and Initial Setup Costs -> $50k.

From the above details, it is impossible to decide on the proposal's feasibility. Hence I cannot agree or disagree with this criteria.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposer stated that he would measure the progress via monthly reports containing information on new users, trading activity and volume, redemption, responses to user feedback, and key demographic indicators. All these details can help assess the success of the proposal. Unfortunately, no metrics are provided to measure the proposal's progress while under execution.

As stated above, the proposer did not provide a detailed plan on how he will build the NFT marketplace, how the NFTs would be linked to the physical collectibles, how they would certify the collectibles, etc. Apart from this, no precise timeframe or delivery dates are mentioned. Instead, the proposer said the team would build the NFT marketplace in 18 weeks.

Also, the budget is not broken into identifiable tasks. This will make it impossible to audit the project from the budget's perspective.

Because of all the above points, I am afraid I have to disagree as it is difficult to audit this proposal's progress.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal links well with the setting that challenges the trading of collectibles via traditional routes which are expensive, time-consuming, and illiquid which is a problem to be solved in the project. This project fits the current challenge. The author plans to build an NFT marketplace where NFTs are backed by certified collectibles. The solution of this proposal is to provide lower costs, easier access and more liquidity than this solution can solve the problem the challenge. The proposal links well with the setting that challenges the trading of collectibles via traditional routes which are expensive, time-consuming, and illiquid which is a problem to be solved in the project. This project fits the current challenge. The author plans to build an NFT marketplace where NFTs are backed by certified collectibles. The solution of this proposal is to provide lower costs, easier access and more liquidity than this solution can solve the problem of challenge. Regarding the risks of the project, there are two main risks: insufficient funding and lack of attention, which affects the success of the proposal. However, the author has also listed workarounds for this problem using other NFT platforms on Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1:
The author has provided a clear roadmap with detailed stages and milestones, a clear vision and targeted goals. The project implementation plan is explained in detail and is expected over the next few months. Authors gather relevant skills in research to provide confidence in their ability to achieve their proposed goals. With the specific goals listed by the author, I think that if funded, the project will be successful.
The success of the proposal is clearly described by the author through the metrics listed by the author:
1. The number of active users using our platform, which the community will be able to see in our monthly report.
2. Growth in different user demographics: crypto community, collectible community, retail investor, institutional investor
3. Questionnaires will be released to determine how many of our users have come from the traditional collection industry.
All of these successes are directly related to the challenge's campaign. The solution to this problem is that the author will create an NFT marketplace that will allow users to trade NFTs backed by certified real-world collections. Our verified marketplace sellers ship their collectibles to our secure, London-based location. Once a verified seller has submitted their items, they will be issued an NFT that can be redeemed for the item by anyone who owns the NFT. Items are fully insured and can easily be inspected by anyone who wishes to do so, as long as this person has been approved by the community. The converted NFT will be burned and permanently removed from circulation. These are the solutions that the proposal has brought to the market. I think this proposal is very good if the project is funded I think the project will be successful.
f6_assessments.q2:
Well-defined KPIs determine the success of the proposal through monthly reporting containing information on new users, trading activity and volume, redemption amount, response to user feedback and key demographic indicators, and community feedback. As a powerful team with 40 years of industry experience. The team includes: Jamie George, Arnas, Tasoma Vilini, Jemini Rock, and the team is also working further with top Haskell developers who are experts: researchers, analysts, chief operations officer, banknote auction leader, coin expert, auction house founder, UI/UX designer, .....The members have detailed each job they are currently doing very clearly and in detail. The funding applied for this project is $250,000 less than 20% of the challenger's budget. The budget is broken down into reasonable amounts: the foundation build is quoted at $150k,
2 employees at $25k/year each, initial setup cost of $50k these expenses fit within the budget of the challenge.
f6_assessments.reply: Thank you for your valuable feedback, it is much appreciated.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal addresses the objectives of the challenge. The project aims to create an NFT marketplace where users can trade NFTs that are backed by physical collectables. NFTs will be minted and issued to the seller when the collectables are deposited at the project's London-based location. Anyone who owns NFT can redeem for collectibles corresponding to their NFT. Creating an NFT marketplace that allows users to redeem physical collectables is an interesting idea and creates real benefits for users. Not only does it bring new utility to NFT, but it also adds new use case to the Cardano ecosystem. Trading collectables through NFTs will help sellers and buyers reduce intermediary costs such as the cost of organizing an auction. Additionally, NFTs can be used as collateral for DeFi loans. From the benefits that the project brings, I rate it 5 stars for the impact of the proposal.
f6_assessments.q1:
The experience and skills of the team members are suitable for carrying out the project. However, the team has not provided evidence for the experiences they mentioned. I found the LinkedIn accounts of Tashoma Vilini and Jemini Rock, for Jamie George and Arnas Savickas, I couldn't find any information on them on google.

Regarding the project implementation plan, the proposal outlined the milestones that the project needs to achieve. However, the specific timelines to implement those milestones have not been specified.

The requested budget needs to be broken down into identifiable items. For example, in the amount of $150k for platform building, it is necessary to specify information such as how long to build, how many employees are needed, how many hours each employee works, and each person's pay rate.

About the cost of 50k setup money for insurance, deposit boxes, and marketing promotion, it also needs to be more specific. It should include information such as how much it costs for insurance, how many deposit boxes to buy, how much each box costs, how much budget to spend on advertising, and on which platforms to advertise.

In addition, the safety of the deposited assets is also one of the factors affecting the success of the project. Therefore, the proposer needs to explain more clearly how they protect these assets to prevent loss from happening.
f6_assessments.q2:
The project's implementation plan already has milestones, but still lacks specific timelines. For example, for users to test the marketplace's testnet, how long does it take to test, when do users start testing, from what time does the mainnet version launch, and so on.

The proposal provided quantifiable KPIs to evaluate the success of the project, which include the number of active users, and the number of users coming from the traditional collectables industry.

The project will provide a monthly report so that the community can audit the progress of the project, but where they provide that report has not been specified. An accessible public channel like Twitter would be a good place to provide these reports.

The information given in the proposal is not enough for the community to audit the progress and success of the project

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal wants to make the trading of real assets easier. The idea is to create an NFT-Marketplace with NTFs backed by real assets. The assets get verified and deposited into their physical location in London. Than a NFT get minted that represents the asset. This creates an easier way to trade and the NFT can be redeemed for the backed asset. This creates a secure easy and cheap market place for easy assets/ collectibles. 
In conclusion this proposal creates a new dApp which can bring new users to Cardano. Therefore it clearly matches the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team described their skills and experience but there isn´t any proof of them. Please provide additional infos or some developed products to show you capability. 
The budget is described shortly. The budget for the employees and initial set-up seems reasonable but the “Platform build quoted at 150K$” is unclear. Please define this in more detail. 
The timeplan is more like a longterm roadmap. It would be nice to how you want to develop the application. You said that you need 18 weeks. What exactly do you want to do in this time. How much time is allocated to design the dApp, to develop the frontend, develop ten backend etc… 
The risks are analyzed. The problem have been addressed and they have proposed solutions. 
Overall the proposal lacks details in every major field of the feasibility. There is not proof for the skills, the budget allocation for the development is unclear and the timeplan misses the shortterm development. Therefore I give 2 stars.
f6_assessments.q2:
The team wants to make monthly reports which include many relevant KPIs and overall many important KPIs and metrics are listed. 
The problem was clearly stated and it get solved by the success goal. The goal isn´t clearly stated but is observable in the context of the whole proposal. Therefore I agree strongly that the proposal is easily auditable.
